# 14\. **What means “rate of change of angular momentum”?**

Consider a moving particle P. Consider also a moving point C (moving relative to a Newtonian frame $\mathcal{F}$ that has an origin 0). For which of these definitions of $\vec{H}_{/C}$ Is the following equation of motion true (that is, consistent with $\vec{F} = m \cdot \vec{a}$)?
$$\vec{M}_C = \dot{\vec{H}}_{/C}$$

In each case say whether the definition works i) in general, or ii) for some special cases (that you name) concerning the motions of P and C.

1. $\vec{H}_{/C} = \vec{r}_{P/C'} \times \vec{v}_{P/0} m$, where C' is a point fixed in $\mathcal{F}$ that instantaneuosly coincides with C.
1. $\vec{H}_{/C} = \vec{r}_{P/C} \times \vec{v}_{P/0} m$.
1. $\vec{H}_{/C} = \vec{r}_{P/C} \times \vec{v}_{P/C} m$.

That is, for each possible definition of $\vec{H}_{/C}$ you need to calculate $\dot{\vec{H}}_{C}$ by differentiation and see if and when you get $\dot{\vec{H}}_{/C} = \vec{r}_{P/C} \times m \vec{a}_{P/\mathcal{F}}$

## $\vec{H}_{/C} = \vec{r}_{P/C'} \times \vec{v}_{P/0} m$, where C' is a point fixed in $\mathcal{F}$ that instantaneuosly coincides with C.

No conditions, this definition is consistent with  $\vec{F} = m \cdot \vec{a}$.

## $\vec{H}_{/C} = \vec{r}_{P/C} \times \vec{v}_{P/0} m$.

This condition is consistent with  $\vec{F} = m \cdot \vec{a}$, only if $\vec{v}_C = \vec{0}$.

## $\vec{H}_{/C} = \vec{r}_{P/C} \times \vec{v}_{P/C} m$.

This condition is consistent with  $\vec{F} = m \cdot \vec{a}$, only if $\vec{a}_C = \vec{0}$.
